summary:
I am a thought leader, entreprener and sustainability professional with over 12 years of business development, policy & regulatory analysis, consultancy, project and stakeholder management experience focused on climate change, international development and green transformation of energy, heavy industry and minerals sectors. 

Main areas of content expertise:
•	Net-zero target setting and roadmapping in the energy and hard to abate industry
•	Methodology development, sustainability certification and standards  
•	Renewable hydrogen policy and regulation and finance solutions for green infrastructure 
•	Advocacy work in climate & energy policy, industry & trade policy and the regulatory landscape

Extensive experience in:
•	Leading corporate engagement, public affairs and climate diplomacy  
•	Setting sustainability and impact strategy
•	Driving business development and fundraising 
•	Leading and delivering complex multi-partner projects 
•	Managing, coaching and leading multi-disciplinary and diverse teams

Brief biography: 

Dr Gokce Mete is Global Lead in heavy industry transition and low-carbon hydrogen at South Pole and leads the Hydrogen for Net Zero Initiative (H2NZ). H2NZ aims to unlock carbon finance for hydrogen projects. She also leads the policy and advocacy efforts of South Pole in the low-carbon hydrogen space and is responsible for developing new low-carbon hydrogen business opportunities. 

Gokce is co-founder of the Women in Green Hydrogen Network, author of over 30 publications, and has over 12 years of policy and regulatory analysis, public affairs, project development and stakeholder management experience focused on climate change, just transition and sustainability in the energy, heavy industry and minerals sectors.

Previously she was Head of Secretariat of the UN Leadership Group for the Industry Transition hosted by the Stockholm Environment Institute which explores how policy, finance and business practices in hard-to-abate industry sectors such as steel, cement, heavy duty transport and chemicals can be aligned to achieve climate neutrality. At SEI, she also project led initiatives focusing on oil and gas transitions, green trade and green public procurement in road transport and construction sectors.

projects.title: Climate Policy Journal Special Issue on Oil and Gas Transitions
projects.description:
This Special Issue will unite the need for market-led oil and gas just transition with net zero emission ambitions, critically analysing the potential for a just transition by 2040. Such a just transition will  ensure due process and fair outcomes for workers and communities across the whole oil and gas value chain. We employ a pathway to 2040 because, even in countries such as Denmark where there is an “oil stop” deadline of 2050, there is an expectation of significant production as late as 2040. The 2021 Production Gap Report, however, finds that compared to global production levels under the 2°C-consistent pathways, governments’ fossil fuel supply production plans and projections would lead to 120% more coal, 14% more oil, and 15% more gas in 2030. The production gaps for all fuels becomes much more significant by 2040 for an under 2°C-or 1.5°C- temperature limit and thus, this timeline needs to be critically assessed.

Globally, we cannot reach the emissions reductions necessary to meet a 1.5°C or even a 2°C target overnight. Evidence from the Oil and Gas Transitions project suggest that net zero targets for oil and gas sector should be more ambitious.

Special Issue papers will ideally engage with a broad geographical scope, either within or across each contribution, including, for example, the United Arab Emirates, Nigeria, Norway and the United Kingdom, in order to showcase both leaders and laggards, developed and emerging economies. Papers will also variously consider a range of barriers and opportunities, including corporate and state-led initiatives.

projects.description:
Co-creating evidence to accelerate policy action in the North Sea

projects.title: Just Transition Initative
projects.description: The Just Transition is a multi-disciplinary initiative towards achieving a Low-Carbon Economy – Integrating Climate, Energy and Environmental Justice. The initiative is supported by academic and research institutions, civil society and governments. Just transition is a development model based on locally designed public policies to create the context for a fair income and a decent life for all workers and communities affected by pollution reduction measures (Alexandru Mustata, Bankwatch Romania. 2017).

projects.title: Extractives Resource Hub
projects.description: An initiative of the UK Department for International Development (DFID), the Extractives Resource Hub will support the development of a digital hub for high-quality, on-demand information, evidence and personalised advice for good management of the extractives sector throughout the lifecycle of the oil, gas and mining industries. It is being implemented by Adam Smith International in partnership with the University of Dundee, Open Oil and technology provider Skotkonung. The project began in December 2015 and continues through November 2019.

projects.title: International Meeting of Experts on Reliable and Stable Transit
projects.description:
The Energy Charter Secretariat and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Turkmenistan are co-organising an International Meeting of Experts on Reliable and Stable Transit of Energy on 22 April 2015 in Brussels. The Meeting will focus on the topic of "Facilitating Investments in New Transit Infrastructure". Discussion points will include the promotion of investments into new and upgrading of existing cross-border and transit infrastructure.
This event comes as a follow-up to the work initiated in cooperation with the government of Turkmenistan on 10-11 December 2014 in Ashgabat under the UN General Assembly Resolution 67/263 "Reliable and Stable Transit of Energy". The aim of the Meeting is to facilitate policy debate within the expert community on setting up a new international legal mechanism that would support and sustain secure energy supplies to world markets.

projects.title: Dundee International Law Society
projects.description:
Dundee International Law Society - DILS - aims to provide a regular opportunity on the beautiful banks of the River Tay for researchers, scholars and practitioners to exchange views on public and private international law and other multidisciplinary subjects.

DILS is a student led society made up of current and former Dundee University students, faculty members as well as scholars and friends from across the wider legal and academic community. We organise regular seminars, colloquia, debates, roundtables and presentations on a wide range of international law problems and prospects, and serve as an informal society for analysis of international law questions both great and small. Practitioners, academics and students are invited to attend, to participate and to present papers or lead discussions.

profile_positions.description:
Core competencies include sustainable business development activities, leadership, corporate engagement, partnership building, network management, fundraising, advocacy and communications.

•	Designing and developing business models and project investment case for low carbon hydrogen, while ensuring internal buy-in and a return on investment
•	Driving business development activities and generating new partnerships to address sustainability challenges related to the topic of renewable hydrogen and industry transition
•	Providing high-quality expert input into climate policy and net-zero strategy advisory projects on ammonia, hydrogen, aluminium, steel, cement & construction sector transition
•	Management of an action platform for global corporations and public sector stakeholders, on which developments in the hydrogen sector (policies, standards, impact investment opportunities) are curated, elaborated and shared
•	Leading the Hydrogen for Net Zero Initiative which aims to create the methodological framework for carbon finance for renewable hydrogen projects (inc. Article 6 transactions)
•	Leading the policy and advocacy efforts of South Pole in the hydrogen space to steer companies towards ambitious and credible corporate climate leadership
profile_positions.title: Global Hydrogen Lead (Climate Investments)

profile_positions.description:
Women in Green Hydrogen is a network of passionate women working in the green hydrogen sector. Our vision is to increase the visibility and amplify the voices of women working in green hydrogen. 
The network provides a platform to connect, empower, and change.
Diversity is essential for a sector that thrives on innovation and new ideas.  Our network works to promote the participation of women in conferences, expert talks, and relevant media to shape a more diverse and inclusive discourse in the world of green hydrogen.

Our goal is to build a community to foster knowledge exchange, connect women in green hydrogen, and create professional opportunities for our members.

We organise networking events and panels about relevant topics in green hydrogen, manage an international expert database, and offer a mentorship programme.  We are also active on Twitter and LinkedIn to increase visibility, promote activities and facilitate exchange.
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder

profile_positions.description: The H2UB is the first Europe-wide hydrogen hub for start-ups, companies and research. We are matchmaker, startup accelerator, ecosystem builder, think tank and service desk for innovation topics related to hydrogen and support start-ups, corporates, technology and science partners from different disciplines, industries and sectors.

profile_positions.description: Climate Strategies works at the science-policy interface, advancing climate policy through meaningful interactions between decision-makers and researchers across Europe and internationally. We are an international, not-for-profit research network with an expansive network of world-leading researchers.
profile_positions.title: Member

profile_positions.description:
Proficiencies employed include climate diplomacy, end-to-end project management, business development, team leadership, consortium relations, using research to influence policy and practice, engaging stakeholders and facilitating policy dialogues.

•	Led SEI’s portfolio of work on industry and energy transitions, including fundraising, network building, internal capacity and team building, knowledge management and input to external communications on hydrogen economy, carbon contracts for difference, carbon border adjustment, carbon capture and storage and green public procurement
•	Managed the CEO-Ministerial level UN Leadership Group for Industry Transition initiative that brings together countries, companies and industry experts to achieve net-zero emissions from heavy industries by 2050
•	Supported various Ministries in India in the design of their steel, cement and ammonia sector decarbonisation strategy, with a focus on creating a business case, through public-private partnerships and regulatory reform 
•	Project led a major initiative focussed that focused on accelerating oil and gas transition in the North Sea region by developing participatory and evidence based net-zero and oil and gas phase out scenarios in Denmark, Norway and the UK 
•	Project managed a Breakthrough Energy Ventures funded project to create greater coherence between policies to reduce GHG emissions in the road transport and construction sectors (covering embedded emissions from e.g. steel, concrete, cement and operational emissions of buildings) and policies on green public procurement targets in the EU
profile_positions.title: Head of Secretariat, Leadership Group for Industry Transition

company.name: Women in Energy, Climate and  Sustainability

profile_positions.company: Women in Energy, Climate and  Sustainability
profile_positions.description:
Women in Energy, Climate and Sustainability (WECS) is a bottom up initiative driven by women in the field of energy and climate. 

It is a public foundation promoting gender equality as a crucial enabler for the transition towards a climate neutral economy in Europe and worldwide.

We have a bold vision for Europe. A Europe, that is a global leader in fighting climate change, and a global champion in unlocking female talent and leadership potential in the energy, climate and sustainability ecosystem. 

We see opportunities for building synergies between the European Gender Strategy and the European Green Deal to form a stepping stone in that direction. 

In order to move towards a common goal, WECS brings together policymakers, the private sector, NGOs and academia through a platform for project development, knowledge sharing and best practice exchange.

My role at the WECS involves heading research and academic engagement; steering of the strategic research agenda and educational activities of the Foundation, alongside a diverse Academic Board.
profile_positions.title: Head of Research and Engagement

profile_positions.description:
Skills performed include project and budget development and management, regulatory affairs, policy and economics research, diplomacy and advocacy skills, ability to influence stakeholders, managing and motivating people, public speaking and excellent communications and interpersonal skills. 

•	Led research, partnerships and content development on the clean energy transition
•	Managed the organisation of training courses for government officials and young professionals with a focus on natural gas, renewable energy and hydrogen
•	Steered the Beijing Energy Research Centre, a cooperation with the China Electricity Council, facilitated by a diverse academic board and a steering committee
•	Formed partnerships with international organisations: i.e.. Leading the OPEC cooperation on the energy transition and decarbonisation of fossil fuels
•	Developed and maintained relations with member states, observer and outreach countries
•	Engaged with industry members and associations such as Solar Power Europe

company.name: AMLA - African Mining Legislation Atlas - ALSF

profile_positions.description: Project Implementation Consortium (PIC)'s function between 2017-2022 is two-fold: i) serves as an advisory body to the African Legislation Support Facility, and ii) collaborates with the AMLA Secretariat, and serves as a knowledge curator, producer and facilitator. In this respect, the PIC takes on a hybrid role and comprises of 14 member institutions, including the The University of Pretoria (South Africa), Werkmans (South Africa), Institut de Droit Communautaire (Cote d'Ivoire), University Eduardo Mondlane (Mozambique), CREDILA - University of Cheikh Anta Diop (Senegal), Women in Mining Africa (Sierra Leone/Ghana), The University of Strathmore (Kenya), The African Institute for International Law - AIIL (Tanzania), The University of Dundee – CEPMLP, The Columbia Centre for Sustainable Investment – CCSI, Norton Rose Fulbright, Natural Resource Governance Institute – NRGI, Latham & Watkins, Lexis Nexis and Vd Academia.
profile_positions.title: Project Implementation Consortium (PIC) Member
